description: From Middle English audience, from Middle French audience, from Old French audience, from Latin audientia, from present participle audiens (“hearing”), from verb audio (“I hear”). Doublet of audiencia.

entries.meaning: A group of people within hearing; specifically, a large gathering of people listening to or watching a performance, speech, etc. [from 15th c.]
examples: We joined the audience just as the lights went down.

entries.meaning: (now rare) Hearing; the condition or state of hearing or listening. [from 14th c.]
A widespread or nationwide viewing or listening public, as of a TV or radio network or program.
A formal meeting with a state or religious dignitary. [from 16th c.]
examples: She managed to get an audience with the Pope.

entries.meaning: The readership of a book or other written publication. [from 19th c.]
examples: "Private Eye" has a small but faithful audience.
The opera singer expanded his audience by singing songs from the shows.

entries.meaning: (historical) An audiencia (judicial court of the Spanish empire), or the territory administered by it.
